docs.title: MkDocs Graph View
docs.text:
Create beautiful, interactive graph visualizations of your documentation structure.

  • Interactive Graphs

    Visualize page connections with force-directed network graphs powered by D3.js

  • Responsive Design

    Automatically adapts to mobile and desktop layouts for optimal viewing

  • Highly Configurable

    Customize physics simulation, visual appearance, and user interactions

  • Theme Integration

    Seamlessly integrates with Material for MkDocs light and dark themes

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The MkDocs Graph Plugin adds interactive network graph visualizations to your MkDocs documentation, inspired by Quartz. It helps readers understand the structure and relationships between pages in your documentation.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Mini Graph View: Shows connected pages in the sidebar
  • Full Graph View: Expandable overlay with the entire documentation graph
  • Smart Filtering: BFS-based depth filtering for performance
  • Tag Support: Display page tags in graph labels
  • Touch Friendly: Full mobile and touch device support
  • Customizable Physics: Control node repulsion, centering, and link distances

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Install using pip:

pip install mkdocs-graph-view

Add to your mkdocs.yml:

plugins:
  - search
  - graph

That's it! Your documentation now has interactive graph visualizations.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Link Extraction: The plugin scans all pages and extracts internal links
  2. Graph Building: Creates a network graph data structure
  3. Smart Filtering: Uses BFS to find connected pages within configured depth
  4. Visualization: Renders interactive graphs using D3.js force simulation
  5. Responsive Layout: Automatically positions graphs based on viewport size

docs.title: Live Demo
docs.text:
Navigate to any page in this documentation to see the graph plugin in action:

  • Check the sidebar for the mini graph view
  • Click the expand button to open the full graph overlay
  • Hover over nodes to highlight connections
  • Click on nodes to navigate to pages

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text:
• enabled - Enable/disable plugin
  • local_graph_depth - Graph depth for mini view
  • global_graph - Enable full graph overlay
  • repel_force - Node repulsion strength
  • center_force - Centering force strength
  • link_distance - Distance between connected nodes
  • scale - Overall graph scale
  • font_size - Label font size
  • show_tags - Display page tags
  • enable_drag - Allow node dragging
  • enable_zoom - Allow zoom and pan
  • focus_on_hover - Highlight on hover

docs.title: Development Setup
docs.text:
1. Fork and clone the repository:
git clone https://github.com/sawyerrensel/mkdocs-graph-view.git
cd mkdocs-graph-view
  1. Create a virtual environment:
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate
  1. Install in development mode:
pip install -e .
pip install -r requirements-dev.txt  # If exists
  1. Test the plugin:
cd docs
mkdocs serve

docs.title: Making Changes
docs.text:
1. Create a feature branch:
git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name
  1. Make your changes:

Edit the relevant files: - mkdocs_graph_plugin/plugin.py - Backend logic - mkdocs_graph_plugin/config.py - Configuration options - mkdocs_graph_plugin/assets/javascripts/graph.js - Frontend visualization - mkdocs_graph_plugin/assets/stylesheets/graph.css - Styling

  1. Test your changes:
mkdocs serve
# Navigate and test the graph functionality
  1. Commit your changes:
git add .
git commit -m "Add feature: description of your changes"
  1. Push and create PR:
git push origin feature/your-feature-name

Then create a Pull Request on GitHub.

docs.title: Python Code Style
docs.text:
• Follow PEP 8
  • Use meaningful variable names
  • Add docstrings to functions
  • Keep functions focused and small

Example: 

def extract_links(html: str) -> list[str]:
    """
    Extract internal links from HTML content.

    Args:
        html: HTML content to parse

    Returns:
        List of internal link URLs
    """
    parser = LinkParser()
    parser.feed(html)
    return parser.links

docs.title: JavaScript Code Style
docs.text:
• Use ES6+ features
  • Add comments for complex logic
  • Keep functions small and focused
  • Use meaningful variable names

Example: 

/**
 * Initialize graph visualization
 * @param {HTMLElement} container - Container element
 * @param {Object} data - Graph data with nodes and links
 * @param {Object} options - Configuration options
 */
function initGraph(container, data, options) {
    // Implementation
}

docs.title: CSS Code Style
docs.text:
• Use Material theme CSS variables
  • Add comments for sections
  • Keep selectors specific but not overly complex

Example: 

/* --- Mini Graph Container --- */
#mini-graph-container {
    width: 100%;
    height: 200px;
    background-color: var(--md-default-bg-color);
}

docs.title: Configuration Examples
docs.text: Real-world configuration examples for different use cases.

docs.title: Minimal Configuration
docs.text:
For most documentation sites, the defaults work great:

plugins:
  - search
  - graph

docs.title: Small Documentation (< 50 pages)
docs.text:
Can afford deeper graph depth and tighter spacing:

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 3      # Show 3 levels deep
      repel_force: 0.5          # Tighter clustering
      link_distance: 30          # Shorter links
      focus_on_hover: true      # Enable hover effects

docs.title: Medium Documentation (50-100 pages)
docs.text:
Balanced configuration for moderate-sized sites:

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 2      # 2 levels deep
      repel_force: 1.0          # Good spacing
      link_distance: 50          # Medium link length
      font_size: 10             # Standard size
      focus_on_hover: true      # Enable hover effects

docs.title: Large Documentation (> 100 pages)
docs.text:
Optimized for performance with many pages:

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 1      # Only direct connections
      repel_force: 0.8          # More spread
      center_force: 0.2         # Less centering
      link_distance: 50          # More space
      font_size: 8              # Smaller labels
      focus_on_hover: false     # Disable for performance

docs.title: Knowledge Base / Wiki
docs.text:
For interconnected documentation with tags:

plugins:
  - tags                        # Enable tags first
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 2
      show_tags: true           # Show tags in labels
      font_size: 11             # Larger for readability
      repel_force: 1.0
      focus_on_hover: true      # Highlight connections

docs.title: API Documentation

Clean, professional appearance:

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 1

      enable_drag: true

docs.title: Compact/Dense Layout
docs.text:
For pages with many connections:

  - graph-view:

docs.title: Options Reference
docs.text: Complete reference for all configuration options.

docs.title: enabled
docs.text:
• Type: bool
  • Default: true
  • Description: Enable or disable the plugin entirely
plugins:
  - graph-view:
      enabled: true

docs.title: local_graph_depth
docs.text:
• Type: int
  • Default: 1
  • Range: 1-5 (recommended)
  • Description: Number of connection levels to show in the mini graph

The plugin uses BFS (Breadth-First Search) to find pages within this depth from the current page.

Examples: - 1: Shows only directly connected pages - 2: Shows connected pages and their connections - 3: Shows 3 levels deep (can get large quickly)

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 2

Warning

Values above 3 can result in very large graphs on interconnected documentation sites.

docs.title: global_graph
docs.text:
• Type: bool
  • Default: true
  • Description: Enable the full-screen graph overlay
plugins:
  - graph-view:
      global_graph: true

docs.title: Physics Simulation
docs.text: These options control the D3.js force-directed layout.

docs.title: repel_force
docs.text:
• Type: float
  • Default: 1.0
  • Range: 0.5-2.0 (recommended)
  • Description: Controls how strongly nodes repel each other

Higher values = more spread out nodes Lower values = tighter clustering

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      repel_force: 1.2

docs.title: center_force
docs.text:
• Type: float
  • Default: 0.2
  • Range: 0.1-0.5 (recommended)
  • Description: Controls how strongly nodes are pulled toward the center

Higher values = stronger centering Lower values = nodes can drift more

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      center_force: 0.3

docs.title: link_distance
docs.text:
• Type: int
  • Default: 50
  • Range: 30-100 (recommended)
  • Description: Target pixel distance between connected nodes
plugins:
  - graph-view:
      link_distance: 60

docs.title: scale
docs.text:
• Type: float
  • Default: 1.1
  • Range: 0.8-1.5 (recommended)
  • Description: Overall scale multiplier for the graph
plugins:
  - graph-view:
      scale: 1.0

docs.title: font_size
docs.text:
• Type: int
  • Default: 10
  • Range: 8-14 (recommended)
  • Description: Font size in pixels for node labels
plugins:
  - graph-view:
      font_size: 12

docs.title: show_tags
docs.text:
• Type: bool
  • Default: false
  • Description: Display page tags in graph node labels

Requires the tags plugin to be enabled.

plugins:
  - tags
  - graph-view:
      show_tags: true

docs.title: enable_drag
docs.text:
• Type: bool
  • Default: true
  • Description: Allow users to drag nodes
plugins:
  - graph-view:
      enable_drag: true

docs.title: enable_zoom
docs.text:
• Type: bool
  • Default: true
  • Description: Allow users to zoom and pan the graph
plugins:
  - graph-view:
      enable_zoom: true

docs.title: focus_on_hover
docs.text:
• Type: bool
  • Default: true
  • Description: Highlight connections when hovering over nodes

Disabling can improve performance on large graphs.

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      focus_on_hover: false

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text:
plugins:
  - search
  - tags
  - graph-view:
      # Plugin control
      enabled: true

      # Graph depth
      local_graph_depth: 2
      global_graph: true

      # Physics
      repel_force: 1.0
      center_force: 0.2
      link_distance: 50

      # Visual
      scale: 1.1
      font_size: 10
      show_tags: true

      # Interaction
      enable_drag: true
      enable_zoom: true
      focus_on_hover: true

docs.title: Configuration Overview
docs.text: The Graph Plugin offers extensive configuration options to customize the appearance, behavior, and performance of your documentation graphs.

docs.title: Graph Depth
docs.text: Controls how many levels of connections to display in the mini graph view.

docs.title: Physics Simulation
docs.text: Controls the force-directed layout behavior: node repulsion, centering, and link distances.

docs.title: Visual Settings
docs.text: Controls the appearance: scale, font sizes, and tag display.

docs.title: Interaction
docs.text: Controls user interactions: dragging, zooming, and hover effects.

docs.title: Configuration File Location
docs.text:
All configuration goes in your mkdocs.yml file under the graph plugin section:

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      # Your configuration here
      local_graph_depth: 2
      repel_force: 1.0
      # ... more options

docs.title: Default Values
docs.text:
If you don't specify an option, these defaults are used:

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      enabled: true
      local_graph_depth: 1
      global_graph: true
      repel_force: 1.0
      center_force: 0.2
      link_distance: 50
      scale: 1.1
      font_size: 10
      show_tags: false
      enable_drag: true
      enable_zoom: true
      focus_on_hover: true

docs.title: Start Simple
docs.text:
Begin with defaults and only customize what you need:

plugins:
  - graph

docs.title: Iterate Based on Results
docs.text:
Build your docs and adjust based on what you see:

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 2  # First adjustment

docs.title: Fine-tune for Your Site
docs.text:
Customize based on your documentation size and structure:

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 2
      repel_force: 0.8
      link_distance: 40
      focus_on_hover: true

docs.title: Too Many Nodes?
docs.text:
Reduce local_graph_depth: 

local_graph_depth: 1

docs.title: Nodes Too Close Together?
docs.text:
Increase repel_force and link_distance: 

repel_force: 1.2
link_distance: 60

docs.title: Labels Too Small?
docs.text:
Increase font_size: 

font_size: 12

docs.title: Performance Issues?
docs.text:
Disable focus_on_hover and reduce depth: 

local_graph_depth: 1
focus_on_hover: false

To install the latest development version from GitHub:

git clone https://github.com/sawyerrensel/mkdocs-graph-view.git
cd mkdocs-graph-view
pip install -e .

docs.text:
Check that the plugin is installed correctly:

python -c "import mkdocs_graph_plugin; print(mkdocs_graph_plugin.__version__)"

Or verify it appears in MkDocs plugins:

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get up and running with the Graph Plugin in minutes.

docs.title: Basic Setup
docs.text:
1. Add the plugin to mkdocs.yml:
plugins:
  - search
  - graph

Tip

The search plugin is included with MkDocs. Always include it when adding other plugins.

  1. Build your documentation:
mkdocs serve
  1. View the graph:

Navigate to any page in your documentation. You'll see: - A mini graph in the sidebar showing connected pages - An expand button to view the full graph - The current page highlighted in the graph

docs.title: Your First Configuration
docs.text:
Let's customize the graph appearance:

plugins:
  - search
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 2      # Show 2 levels of connections
      repel_force: 1.0           # Spacing between nodes
      link_distance: 50          # Link length
      font_size: 10              # Label size

Save and reload. You'll notice: - More connected pages visible (depth: 2) - Nodes are well-spaced - Labels are easy to read

docs.title: Minimal Configuration
docs.text:
For most documentation sites:

plugins:
  - graph

docs.title: Knowledge Base
docs.text:
For wikis and interconnected documentation:

plugins:
  - tags
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 2
      show_tags: true
      focus_on_hover: true

docs.title: Large Documentation
docs.text:
For sites with 100+ pages:

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 1
      repel_force: 0.8
      focus_on_hover: false

docs.title: Mini Graph (Sidebar)
docs.text:
• Shows the current page and its connections
  • Depth controlled by local_graph_depth
  • Automatically hides on mobile (moves to bottom of content)

docs.title: Full Graph (Overlay)
docs.text:
• Click the expand button to open
  • Shows all pages in your documentation
  • Pan by dragging, zoom with scroll wheel
  • Click nodes to navigate

docs.title: Node Colors
docs.text:
• Blue (Primary): Current page
  • Gray: Other pages
  • Orange (Accent): Hovered page

docs.title: Overriding Colors
docs.text:
You can override graph colors using CSS in your docs/stylesheets/extra.css:

/* Change current page color */
.graph-node.active {
    fill: #ff6600 !important;
}

/* Change hover color */
.graph-node:hover {
    fill: #00ff00 !important;
}

/* Change link color */
.graph-link {
    stroke: #666666 !important;
}

Add to mkdocs.yml: 

extra_css:
  - stylesheets/extra.css

docs.title: Adjusting Graph Container
docs.text:
Customize the mini graph container:

#mini-graph-container {
    height: 300px !important;  /* Make taller */
    border: 2px solid #333 !important;
    border-radius: 8px !important;
}

docs.title: With Tags Plugin
docs.text:
Display page tags in graph labels:

plugins:
  - tags
  - graph-view:
      show_tags: true

Tags appear in brackets after page titles: Page Title [tag1, tag2]

docs.title: With Search Plugin
docs.text:
The graph complements search by providing visual navigation:

plugins:
  - search
  - graph

Users can: - Search for pages by name - Use graph to understand relationships

docs.title: With Blog Plugin
docs.text:
Great for showing relationships between blog posts:

plugins:
  - blog
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 2
      show_tags: true

docs.title: For Large Sites (500+ pages)
docs.text:
plugins:
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 1      # Minimize nodes
      focus_on_hover: false     # Disable expensive hover
      global_graph: false       # Disable full graph
      enable_drag: false        # Reduce interactions
      enable_zoom: false

docs.title: Lazy Loading
docs.text: The full graph is lazy-loaded only when the expand button is clicked, not on page load.

docs.title: Efficient Filtering
docs.text:
The plugin uses BFS (Breadth-First Search) algorithm for efficient depth-based filtering:

# Efficient O(n) filtering instead of O(n²)
BFS from current page → Find nodes within depth → Filter

docs.title: Accessing Graph Data
docs.text:
The graph data is available at /graph.json:

fetch('/graph.json')
  .then(res => res.json())
  .then(data => {
    console.log('Nodes:', data.nodes);
    console.log('Links:', data.links);
  });

docs.title: Graph Data Structure
docs.text:
{
  "nodes": [
    {
      "id": "page/path/",
      "title": "Page Title",
      "tags": ["tag1", "tag2"],
      "group": 1
    }
  ],
  "links": [
    {
      "source": "page/a/",
      "target": "page/b/",
      "value": 1
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: Per-Page Control (Frontmatter)
docs.text:
Hide the graph on individual pages using frontmatter:

---
hide:
  - graph
---

# Page Title

This page won't display the graph view.

This works just like hiding the table of contents or navigation in MkDocs Material theme.

docs.title: Global Control (Environment Variables)
docs.text:
Use conditional configuration with environment variables:

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      enabled: !ENV [ENABLE_GRAPH, true]

Then control per-build: 

ENABLE_GRAPH=false mkdocs build

docs.title: Different Configs for Dev vs Production
docs.text:
plugins:
  - graph-view:
      # Use env variable with fallback
      local_graph_depth: !ENV [GRAPH_DEPTH, 1]
      focus_on_hover: !ENV [GRAPH_HOVER, true]

Development: 

GRAPH_DEPTH=3 GRAPH_HOVER=true mkdocs serve

Production: 

GRAPH_DEPTH=1 GRAPH_HOVER=false mkdocs build

docs.title: Depth Filtering (BFS)
docs.text:
The plugin uses Breadth-First Search to find connected nodes:

  1. Start at current page
  2. Add to queue with distance 0
  3. For each node in queue:
  4. If distance < max_depth:
    • Add neighbors to queue
    • Mark as visited
  5. Return all visited nodes

docs.title: Link Deduplication
docs.text:
Multiple links between same pages are counted and weighted:

# Before: Multiple links
A → B
A → B
A → B

# After: Single weighted link
A →(weight=3)→ B

docs.title: Graph Not Showing
docs.text:
Check browser console for errors: 

// Expected output
Graph plugin: Generated graph with X nodes and Y links

docs.title: Incorrect Connections
docs.text: The plugin only detects <a href="..."> links in rendered HTML. Ensure: - Links are properly formatted - URLs are relative or absolute internal links - Links are not in code blocks (unless intended)

docs.title: Performance Issues
docs.text: Monitor with browser DevTools: 1. Open Performance tab 2. Record page load 3. Check for long-running scripts 4. Consider reducing local_graph_depth

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text: Learn how to use the Graph Plugin effectively in your documentation.

docs.title: Mini Graph (Sidebar)
docs.text:
The mini graph appears in the sidebar on desktop and at the bottom of the content on mobile.

Features: - Shows the current page (highlighted in blue) - Shows connected pages within configured depth - Updates automatically when navigating - Click nodes to navigate to pages - Drag nodes to rearrange (if enabled)

When You See It: - Desktop: Top of the right sidebar - Mobile: Bottom of page content

docs.title: Full Graph (Overlay)
docs.text:
Click the expand button in the mini graph to open the full graph overlay.

Features: - Shows all pages in your documentation - Pan by dragging the background - Zoom with mouse wheel or pinch gesture - Click nodes to navigate - Click background or X button to close

docs.title: Click to Navigate
docs.text:
Click any node in either graph view to navigate to that page.

[Graph Node] → Click → [Navigate to Page]

docs.title: Hover to Explore
docs.text:
Hover over nodes to see connections highlighted (if focus_on_hover is enabled).

What Happens: - Hovered node grows slightly - Connected links become opaque - Unconnected nodes fade - Connected nodes stay visible

docs.title: Drag to Rearrange
docs.text:
Drag nodes to manually position them (if enable_drag is enabled).

Behavior: - Dragged node follows cursor - Physics simulation continues around it - Release to let it settle into new position

docs.title: Understanding Node Colors
docs.text: Color Meaning Blue (Primary) Current page you're viewing Gray Other pages in your documentation Orange (Accent) Hovered page

docs.title: Direct Connections (Depth 1)
docs.text:
Pages with links to/from the current page:

Current Page ←→ Connected Page

docs.title: Indirect Connections (Depth 2+)
docs.text:
Pages connected through other pages:

Current Page ←→ Intermediate Page ←→ Distant Page

docs.title: Finding Related Content
docs.text:
1. Open any page
  2. Look at the mini graph
  3. See what pages link to/from this page
  4. Click to explore related content

docs.title: Understanding Documentation Structure
docs.text:
1. Click the expand button
  2. View the full graph
  3. Observe clusters of related pages
  4. Navigate to areas of interest

docs.title: Discovering Isolated Pages
docs.text:
Pages with no connections appear as single nodes (only visible on their own page).

This indicates: - Page has no internal links - Page is not linked from other pages - Consider adding connections for better navigation

docs.title: On Desktop
docs.text:
• Use the sidebar mini graph for quick navigation
  • Hover to see connections
  • Click expand for full overview

docs.title: On Mobile
docs.text:
• Scroll to bottom of page for mini graph
  • Tap expand button for full view
  • Use pinch-to-zoom for better visibility
  • Tap nodes to navigate

docs.title: Keyboard Users
docs.text:
• Tab through nodes in the graph
  • Enter to navigate to selected node
  • Escape to close full graph overlay

docs.title: Mini Graph is Empty
docs.text:
Possible Reasons: - Current page has no links to/from other pages - Graph depth is set too low - Page is isolated in documentation

Solution: Check page content and add relevant links.

docs.title: Too Many Nodes
docs.text: Solution: Site administrator should reduce local_graph_depth in configuration.

docs.title: Graph Performs Slowly
docs.text: Solution: Site administrator should disable focus_on_hover or reduce graph depth.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text: Guidelines for optimal graph plugin usage and documentation structure.

docs.title: Create Meaningful Connections
docs.text:
Link related pages to create useful graphs:

✅ Good: 

See [Installation Guide](installation.md) for setup instructions.
Related: [Configuration](config.md), [Troubleshooting](troubleshooting.md)

❌ Bad: 

Isolated page with no links.

docs.title: Use Consistent Linking Patterns
docs.text:
Establish patterns for how pages link to each other:

Hub-and-Spoke: 

Overview Page
├── Feature A
├── Feature B
└── Feature C

Sequential: 

Step 1 → Step 2 → Step 3 → Step 4

Cross-Referenced: 

Concept A ←→ Concept B ←→ Concept C

docs.title: Avoid Orphan Pages
docs.text:
Every page should have at least one incoming or outgoing link:

---
# At minimum, link back to index
[← Back to Home](../index.md)
---

docs.title: Start with Defaults
docs.text:
Begin with default configuration and adjust based on results:

plugins:
  - graph  # Start here

Then customize: 

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 2  # Adjust as needed

docs.title: Match Config to Site Size
docs.text: Site Size Recommended Depth Hover Effects < 50 pages 2-3 Enabled 50-100 pages 2 Enabled 100-500 pages 1 Enabled > 500 pages 1 Disabled

docs.title: Test on Real Data
docs.text:
Don't guess at configuration - build and test:

  1. mkdocs serve
  2. Navigate to various pages
  3. Check graph appearance
  4. Adjust configuration
  5. Repeat

docs.title: For Large Documentation
docs.text:
Optimize for performance:

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      local_graph_depth: 1       # Minimize nodes
      focus_on_hover: false      # Reduce JS work
      enable_drag: false         # Simplify interactions

docs.title: Monitor Build Time
docs.text:
Check how the plugin affects build time:

time mkdocs build

If slow, consider: - Reducing graph depth - Disabling features - Using conditional enabling

docs.title: Lazy Load Full Graph
docs.text: The full graph is lazy-loaded by default - don't change this unless necessary.

docs.title: Link Contextually
docs.text:
Add links where they make sense in content:

✅ Good: 

For installation instructions, see the [Installation Guide](install.md).

❌ Bad: 

Related pages: [Install](install.md) [Config](config.md) [API](api.md)

docs.title: Use Descriptive Link Text
docs.text:
Help users understand what they'll find:

✅ Good: 

[Learn how to configure the plugin](configuration.md)

❌ Bad: 

[Click here](configuration.md)

docs.title: Balance Links
docs.text:
Too few = disconnected graph Too many = cluttered graph

Aim for: 3-7 outgoing links per page

docs.title: Readable Font Sizes
docs.text:
Choose font sizes appropriate for your theme:

Material Theme: 10-12px Other Themes: Test and adjust

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      font_size: 10  # Start here

docs.title: Balanced Spacing
docs.text:
Adjust spacing so nodes don't overlap but aren't too sparse:

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      repel_force: 1.0     # Adjust between 0.5-1.5
      link_distance: 50     # Adjust between 30-70

docs.title: Test Both Themes
docs.text:
If your site has dark mode, test graph in both:

  1. Switch to dark mode
  2. Check label visibility
  3. Verify color contrast
  4. Adjust if needed

docs.title: Mobile-Friendly Config
docs.text:
Optimize for touch devices:

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      font_size: 12          # Larger for mobile
      enable_drag: true      # Touch drag
      enable_zoom: true      # Pinch zoom
      focus_on_hover: false  # Better for touch

docs.title: Test on Mobile
docs.text:
Always test on actual mobile devices:

  1. Build documentation
  2. View on phone/tablet
  3. Check graph positioning
  4. Verify interactions work
  5. Adjust configuration

docs.title: Provide Alternative Navigation
docs.text:
Don't rely solely on graph for navigation:

  • Include navigation sidebar
  • Add breadcrumbs
  • Provide search functionality
  • Use clear page hierarchies

docs.title: Descriptive Page Titles
docs.text:
Page titles appear as node labels:

✅ Good: "Installation Guide" ❌ Bad: "Guide" or "Page 1"

docs.title: Keyboard Access
docs.text:
Ensure graph is keyboard-accessible:

  • Tab through nodes
  • Enter to navigate
  • Escape to close overlay

docs.title: Regular Audits
docs.text:
Periodically check your graph:

  1. Build documentation
  2. Open full graph view
  3. Look for isolated nodes
  4. Check for unexpected connections
  5. Fix broken links

docs.title: Document Your Configuration
docs.text:
Add comments to your configuration:

plugins:
  - graph-view:
      # Depth of 2 works well for our ~75 pages
      local_graph_depth: 2

      # Disabled for performance on mobile
      focus_on_hover: false

docs.title: Version Control
docs.text:
Track configuration changes in git:

git log -p mkdocs.yml  # See config history

docs.title: Too Deep Depth
docs.text: ❌ Don't set local_graph_depth: 5 on large sites ✅ Use local_graph_depth: 1-2

docs.title: Too Many Features Enabled
docs.text: ❌ Don't enable every feature on large sites ✅ Disable what you don't need for performance

docs.title: Inconsistent Link Styles
docs.text: ❌ Don't mix absolute and relative links randomly ✅ Choose one style and stick to it

docs.title: Ignoring Mobile
docs.text: ❌ Don't only test on desktop ✅ Always test mobile layout and interactions

docs.title: No Testing
docs.text: ❌ Don't change config without testing ✅ Test every configuration change
